citation.article-title: Allisonella histaminiformans gen. nov., sp. nov. A novel bacterium that produces histamine, utilizes histidine as its sole energy source, and could play a role in bovine and equine laminitis.

p.s: Allisonella (Al.li.son.ella M.L. dim .ending ella; M.L. fem.n Allisonella, named after American microbiologist M.J. Allison, a prominent rumen microbiologist that previously isolated Oxalobacter formigenes, a ruminal bacterium that decarboxylates oxalate)
Cells are ovoid shaped (0.4–0.8 × 1.0–8.0 μm long), are non-motile and occur in diploid or chain form.
Cells stain Gram-negative and are highly resistant to the ionophore, monensin.
Non-fermentative facultative anaerobic chemoheterotroph that utilizes histidine, producing histamine and CO2 as end-products.
Growth occurs in medium that contains yeast extract, butyrate and histidine.
The type species is Allisonella histaminiformans.
